me.wobblyyyy.pathfinder2.follower

Interface Follower

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    GenericFollower

    public interface Follower
    Every rose has its thorns. And every trajectory has its follower. That doesn't sound as catchy, but I'm sure you get the idea.

    Each trajectory that you'd like the robot to follow needs to have a follower responsible for... well, actually following the trajectory.

    Since:
    0.0.0
    Author:
    Colin Robertson

    • Method Detail

      • getTrajectory

        Trajectory getTrajectory()
        Get the trajectory the follower is following.

        This method is mostly just here to enforce that any classes implementing the Follower interface require a trajectory in the constructor.

        Returns:
        the trajectory the follower is following.

      • tick

        boolean tick(PointXYZ current,
             java.util.function.Consumer<Translation> consumer)
        "Tick" the follower once.

        Each time the follower is ticked, a new translation should be generated. The Consumer<Translation> that's supplied to this method will accept that translation, and in doing so, drive the robot accordingly. This translation will always be relative, meaning relative to whatever direction the robot is currently facing.

        Parameters:
        current - the robot's current position.
        consumer - a consumer that will accept a generated translation. This translation should never have X or Y values outside the bounds (-1.0, 1.0).
        Returns:
        if the follower has finished, return true, indicating that the follower can be de-queued and the next follower can begin execution. If the follower has not finished, however, return false, indicating that we need to keep going at least a little while longer.

      • getAbsoluteTranslation

        static Translation getAbsoluteTranslation(PointXYZ current,
                                          PointXYZ target,
                                          double speed,
                                          double turn)
        Get an absolute translation based on a couple of parameters.

        This method functions as follows.

        • Determine the angle from the robot's current position to the robot's target position.
        • Create an imaginary point using the lovely PointXYZ.inDirection(double, Angle) method. This point will always be drawn at a distance of 1. The point's angle is equal to the angle we just calculated.
        • Convert that point into a translation by getting the X and Y values of the point. The generated translation simply re-uses the turn parameter that's passed into this method.

        Parameters:
        current - the robot's current position.
        target - the robot's target point / marker.
        speed - the speed at which the robot should move.
        turn - how much the robot should turn.
        Returns:
        an absolute translation. This translation will always have X and Y values that fit within the bounds (-1.0, 1.0). This translation is also absolute, NOT relative.

      • getRelativeTranslation

        static Translation getRelativeTranslation(PointXYZ current,
                                          PointXYZ target,
                                          double speed,
                                          double turn)
        Get a relative translation by first generating an absolute translation and then converting it into a relative one.
        Parameters:
        current - the robot's current position.
        target - the robot's target point / marker.
        speed - the speed at which the robot should move.
        turn - how much the robot should turn.
        Returns:
        a relative translation. This translation, like any absolute translation, will always have X and Y values that fit within the bounds (-1.0, 1.0). The Z aspect of the translation will always be equal to whatever turn value is provided.
